message: As we enter 2017, Wrenzie and I want to wish everyone a Happy New Year! May this year bring joy and good fortune to you and your family!
Today I will be sworn in for my third term as Congressman from the 7th District of South Carolina. My job is to represent you, so I want to know- what are your top priorities for this Congress?
Just joined my House colleagues in voting to stop President Obama's last minute Midnight Rules– costly and politically motivated regulations that he's been implementing on his way out of office.

You probably haven't seen this in the mainstream news, but it has been gaining some traction and I wanted to bring it to your attention. Each year, members of Congress choose a winning portrait from a student in their district to be displayed in the United States Capitol. The picture below was chosen by Rep. Lacy Clay of Missouri and has since been taken down because it depicts police officers as pigs in uniforms. Rep. Clay says it is a right of free speech, but many others (including police unions) are outraged at the depiction. What do you think?

I’ve heard countless stories from constituents all across the Grand Strand and Pee Dee about how Obamacare is failing them. Premiums and deductibles are both soaring, small business owners can’t afford to cover their employees, and millennials have no options. Obamacare must be repealed and replaced.
Good luck, Clemson Football! Hoping tonight's rematch against Alabama results in a National Title! Go Tigers!!!

During her six years as the head of our state, Governor Nikki Haley has been a credit to South Carolina and to our country. She has led us through natural disasters and devastation and helped to restore competitiveness in South Carolina through job creation and business-friendly policies that grow our economy.   I thank her for her service to South Carolina and look forward to her confirmation as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, where I know she will continue to serve faithfully and selflessly.

In the midst of battle during the Vietnam War, a young African American man named Ralph Johnson threw himself on a grenade, sacrificing his life to save the lives of his compatriots. The blast killed him instantly but his selfless actions saved the lives of his fellow Marines and prevented the enemy from gaining ground.   The USS Ralph Johnson, a Navy warship, was named in his honor and now will be commissioned in Charleston, the city where Mr. Johnson was born and raised. I can think of no better way to honor such an American hero.

Today we celebrate and remember the life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. His commitment to unifying our nation and uplifting all Americans made this a better nation and inspired the world. Today, I encourage everyone to take his words to heart: "Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that."

Today I voted to take the first steps toward giving Congress the power to repeal and replace Obamacare. Right now in our district and across the country, people are suffering under this law. It is a failure by nearly every measure and if nothing is done, it will only get worse. In the weeks ahead several more steps will be taken to fully repeal and replace this law so we can keep our promise to the American people. For those currently on Obamacare, we are not going to pull the rug out from underneath you. Our goal is a stable transition of reforms that empower patients with real choice and coverage that is truly affordable.

President Trump is absolutely right. Like him, I consider myself an environmentalist. As a hunter and fisherman, I believe we need to take care of our environment, but there has to be some test of reasonableness. It's too easy for obstructionists to delay badly-needed and already approved infrastructure projects, often for many years at the cost of taxpayers. In the Seventh District alone we've seen this with the Highway 31 extension, International Drive, and I-73. It's time to put an end to fringe environmental obstructionists that take advantage of the law to delay these much-needed projects.

On the surface, the CFPB seems like a good idea. But once you dig deeper, you'll find a federal government agency that is accountable to no one and gives tremendous amounts of power to unelected bureaucrats in Washington.   As my colleague Jeb Hensarling writes in the below op-ed, "This tyranny has harmed the very consumers it purports to help. The number of banks offering free checking has drastically declined, while many bank fees have increased. Mortgage originations and auto loans have become more expensive for many Americans. The CFPB has eroded freedom, trampled due process and killed jobs. It must go."

Wow friends, what a night! I try very hard to be accessible to you all the time. This industry provides our workforce with innovative, good-paying jobs and I'll continue to work to keep these opportunities and companies on our shores.

Florence is on a roll!  With steady industrial investment and the resulting job creation, its economy is doing well.  Downtown Florence is being reborn.    It is a shining example of the fruits of good infrastructure. The intersection of I95 and I20, good local leadership and its status as a regional healthcare provider all add to the mix. This facility WILL ATTRACT INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT AND HIGH PAYING JOBS to Marion, Dillon and Marlboro counties.  Add to that a new interstate 73, and our future is mighty bright! More South Carolinians had their plans cancelled by Obamacare than have signed up for it. When major provisions of Obamacare went into law in 2013, more than 232,000 individuals had their plans canceled forever. Today, Obamacare enrollment numbers are around 230,000. Clearly, this law isn’t helping South Carolinians the way it was intended. We’re working on a plan that will be less disruptive than Obamacare while offering more choice and lower costs.

Great news of President Trump scrapping the WOTUS rule that changed part of the Clean Water Act.The Clean Water Act was passed in 1972 to regulate pollution levels of water systems in America, and since then the Army Corps has done a terrific job keeping waterways clean and environmentally sound.   However, with the progressive Obama administration came the WOTUS rule, which redefined a part of the Clean Water Act to make all waterways in the United States subject to bureaucratic rules, allowing even bodies of water like ditches to be regulated by the federal government. I heard from South Carolina farmers, landowners, and other small business owners about how burdensome this new designation was to them.   WOTUS is exactly the type of unnecessary regulation that strangles our economy and holds us back from being competitive. I’m glad to see President Trump taking action to undo it.

Dodd-Frank was designed to address "too big to fail banks" but now the big banks like it and small banks are the ones suffering. I'm on the side of Carolinas Credit Union League and all small banks and will continue to fight against these harmful regulations.

I met a lot of great people today at coffee in Lake View but I was especially blessed to meet Mr. & Mrs. Johnson. He is 86 and she is 80, she's a retired school teacher and he is a retired minister. He was married 61 years and she was married for 51 years before both of their spouses passed. The two had been friends for years and just tied the knot last December. As Mr. Johnson said of his bride, "she tells the truth, she reads the Bible, and she's kind." May God continue to bless this wonderful couple.

Today I held coffee events in Lake View, Clio, and Patrick and in between events I got to travel to so many great places in our district and meet so many great people. I met Matt Hayes, owner of Hayes Hardware store in Lake View. Right next door, Keith Tucker owns a local pharmacy after working 18 years for a chain pharmacy company. In Clio, I met Allen Lytch, owner of Awesome Deals consignment store. And in Patrick we met Chris Gainey who serves up the biggest double cheeseburger at Bill's Grill. This is America, right in our backyard.   Along the way we saw beautiful canola fields, the mill pond in Lake View, an old cotton mill, and even stopped by one of our district's most recognized landmarks- South of the Border!  At the end of the day, we all didn't agree on everything but that's okay. What we did find is that more often than not we had more areas of common ground than areas where we disagreed. What's important is we all have a united goal of working to uplift everyone in the Seventh District and ultimately that's what will move us forward. I am absolutely blessed to represent such great people and such a beautiful district!

The Seventh District is vastly different from the coast to Chesterfield County, but in many of these areas people are facing the same issues. Today in Darlington I sat down with Mayor Gloria Hines and local community and ministry leaders about problems they're facing in their community. There’s been a lot of misleading information out there on Medicaid reform and health care, but the truth is, Medicaid is in desperate need of reform. Right now, the neediest Medicaid recipients in the poorest states are being penalized because the wealthier states have been able to receive the lion’s share of federal Medicaid funds.   As this article states, eligibility for Medicaid has been loosened, resulting in enormous disparities. For example, in 2015, Connecticut received $12,240 in federal Medicaid funds per resident under the poverty line, while Alabama was able to claim only $4,070.  The way the federal funding is administered now means Medicaid residents in states like South Carolina are at a disadvantage just because of where they live. We need to get to a place of equity so that Medicaid can be fairly administered and restored to its original intent: helping the poorest, most needy among us.

Many commented on the article I posted yesterday about the need to reform Medicaid, saying the only reason it is broken is because South Carolina didn’t expand Medicaid under Obamacare. The expansion of Medicaid under Obamacare just increased the number of people covered; it had nothing to do with per capita federal spending caps.   The way the federal Medicaid funding works now is for every dollar a state puts in, the federal government contributes $1-$3. Did you know that the first African American to serve in the United States House of Representatives was from the Grand Strand? Joseph Rainey was born into slavery in Georgetown in 1832. His father was a barber and used his earnings to buy freedom for himself and his family, including Joseph. Joseph was conscripted into the Confederate Army during the Civil War.  He was elected to Congress as a Republican in 1870 where he served until 1879. What an amazing life!    Here are a few pictures of his house and memorial in Georgetown. The American dream, it's what separates us from the rest of the world.  It promises that with hard work and determination you can improve your station in life, and that your children have the opportunity for a better life than yours. But for many in the generation coming of age in the last decade, the American dream has been a little tarnished and just out of reach.  The last time we did tax reform was 30 years ago. At that time, we were the world’s uncontested economic leader. Our economic system and tax code were competitive. But for decades we have sat idly as the world restructured to pass us by.  As we became less competitive, more and more American companies and American jobs left our shores.  And what has been the result?  We've lost millions of middle class jobs.  In 1990, the middle class was comprised of about 50% of American families. Today, it is only 40%.  Even worse, the middle class today makes just about the same take-home pay as it did in 1990.    When we all worry about income disparity and the gulf between the rich and the poor in this country, this is the source of the problem.  The American middle class is smaller and has not had a raise in 30 years!!!  How could this happen?  It has everything to do with a bloated, over regulating and overtaxing federal government – a government that sucks the life out of the economy and forces our companies, our innovators, our job creators out of our country to survive.  Some folks say that it doesn't matter that we have the highest business tax rate in the world.  That's not why our companies left. They say those jobs aren't coming back.   Well, I say, the outdated tax code is an anchor around the neck of our businesses, innovators, and middle class. I say, the American worker can compete with anyone on a level playing field, if we can just get government off their back.  Since January, Congress has been working with President Trump to correct that. We have made dramatic steps in reducing regulation. You are already seeing the economic lift.   Today, we passed a tax cut, which will restore economic growth, put more take home pay into the pockets of hard working Americans, and restore opportunity for a generation of Americans.  It will bring American jobs back to America.   It will grow our middle class. And finally, after 30 years of stagnation, it will give our middle class the pay raise it deserves!!!
